1.q_string: A ball is thrown with an initial velocity of \(20 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\). Find the time of flight by the body. (Take \(\mathrm{g}=10 \mathrm{~ms}^{-2}\) )
In the first 10s of a body’s motion, the velocity changes from 10 m/s to 20m/s. During the next 30s the velocity changes from 20m/s to 50m/s. What is the average acceleration in m/s2?

q_option: Both will travel with the same speed
1.q_string: A coin and a bag full of rocks are thrown in a gravity less environment with the same initial speed. Which one of the following statements is true about the situation?
How many variables are required to fully describe a system in uniformly accelerated motion?
A car moves for 60s covering a distance of 3600 m with zero initial velocity. What is the acceleration in m/s2?
Displacement \(y\) (in \(m\) ) of a body varies with time \(t\) (in sec) as: \(y=\frac{-2}{3} t^2+16 t+2\). How long does the body take to come to rest?

q_option: the two arrows will be at the same height above the ground at t = 10 s
the two arrows will reach back to their starting points at t = 20 s and t = 30 s
the ratio of the speed of the first arrow and that of the second arrow at t = 20 s will be 2 : 1
the maximum height attained by either arrow will be 980 m
1.q_string: At t = 0, an arrow is fired vertically upwards with a speed of 98 ms-1. A second arrow is fired vertically upwards with the same speed at t = 5 s. Then,

The acceleration of a particle starting from rest varies with time according to the relation a = kt + c, where k and c are constants of motion.

    The velocity v of the particle after a time t will be:

Two trains each of length \(50 \mathrm{~m}\) are running with constant speeds on parallel tracks while moving in the same direction one overtakes the other in \({4 0}\) seconds and while moving in the opposite direction one crosses the other in 20 seconds. The speeds of trains will be:

The driver of train A moving at a speed of \(30 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) sights another train \(B\) moving on the same track at a speed of \(10 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) in the same direction. He immediately applies brakes and achieves a uniform retardation of \(2 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\) To avoid collision, the minimum distance between the trains must be:
A body moving in a straight line with constant acceleration of 10 ms-2 covers a distance of 40 m in the 4th second. How much distance will it cover in the 6th second?

A body moving in a straight line with an initial velocity of \(5 \mathrm{~ms}^{-1}\) and a constant acceleration covers a distance of \(30 \mathrm{~m}\) in the \(3^{\text {rd }}\) second. How much distance will it cover in the next 2 seconds?

A body, starting from rest and moving with a constant acceleration, covers a distance \(S_1\) in the \(4^{\text {th }}\) second and a distance \(S_2\) in the \(6^{\text {th }}\) second. The ratio \(\frac{S_1}{S_2}\) is:

A car starting from rest is accelerated at a constant rate \(\alpha\) until it attains a speed \(v\). It is then retarded at a constant rate \(\beta\) until it comes to rest. The average speed of the car for its entire journey is:
The displacement of a body from a reference point is given by \(\sqrt{x}=2 t+3\), where \(\mathrm{x}\) is in metres and \(t\) is in seconds. This shows that the body is:
The displacement of a body from a reference point is given by: \(\sqrt{x}=2 t+3\), where \({x}\) is in metres and \({t}\) is in seconds. What is the initial velocity of the body?

The distance \(x\) covered by a body moving in a straight line in time \(t\) is given by:

\(x^2=t^2+2 t+3\)

The acceleration of the body will vary as:

Displacement \((\mathrm{x})\) of a particle is related to time \((\mathrm{t})\) as \(x=a t+b t^2-c t^3\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants of motion. The velocity of the particle, when its acceleration is zero, is given by:
The position of an object moving in a straight line can be specified with reference to:

q_option: Position to the right of the origin is taken as positive and to the left as negative.
Position to the left of the origin is taken as positive and to the right as negative.
1.q_string: For motion in a straight line:

q_option: the distance from origin to maximum point
the total length of the path traversed by an object
the distance from origin to minimum point
1.q_string: Path length is defined as:
A stone falls from a cliff and travels \(34.3 \mathrm{~m}\) in the last second before it reaches the ground. Calculate the height of the cliff.

A man walks on a straight road from his home to a market 2.5 km away with a speed of 5 km/h. Finding the market closed, he instantly turns and walks back home with a speed of 7.5 km/h. If the total time of travel is 40 min find the average speed of the man for the whole journey.

The acceleration a (in \(\mathrm{ms}^{-2}\) ) of a body, starting from rest varies with time \(t\) (in s) following the equation \(a=3 t+4\). The velocity of the body at time \(t=2 \mathrm{~s}\) will be:
The position \(x\) of a particle varies with time \(t\) as \(x=a t^2-b t^3\). For what value of \(t\) acceleration is zero?
The acceleration (a) of a particle is plotted on the \(Y\)-axis while the time (t) elapsed is plotted along the X-axis. What does the a - t graph give?
The displacement \((\mathrm{x})\) of a particle is given by, \(\mathrm{x}=2 \mathrm{t}\). Find the acceleration of the particle.

q_option: When the body is always under rest.
When the body is always under motion.
1.q_string: When will a body have zero speed?
A bus is travelling with a speed of \(72 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}\). What will be its speed in \(\mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\) ?
Find acceleration of a bike, if starting from rest it covers a distance of \(x\) in \(t\) time.
